comments.commentBody: I would also add that there are strong vested interest in installing billions of dollars of new security equipment. It would be noteworthy to check on the lobbying going on by the manufacturers in Washington. One has to remember that what happens in the USA will usually be replicated around the world. Here in Thailand, when they opened the new Bangkok airport, the scandals and corruption were rife concerning all the hundreds of millions of new GE X ray scanners. Now repeat that in thousands of airports around the world and tell me there is no incentive to push this new unnecessary made in USA tech.

Professor Barnett, I'd really like to know the basis for your belief that the scanners provide any effective security, particularly in the hands of screeners well known for their widely varying and inconsistent levels of competence and training? That's what seems to be missing from the debate.

We're supposed to accept as an unquestioned postulate the TSA's claims that what they do is effective and necessary. But the only evidence they can offer is "that's classified, so trust us." Unfortunately, the TSA has given us little if any reason to trust them.

As even Administrator Pistole admits, the scanners are "invasive," and the alternative pat down is even more so (even when it's not being used as a punitive measure to "encourage" passengers to choose the scanner). The scanners carry a high cost, in liberties, privacy, and dignity as well as dollars. The scanners also carry some risk of cumulative radiation exposure that's probably small but it is there. That risk is increased because of the opacity of the operating and maintenance procedures that make it impossible to be sure the TSA is operating and maintaining the machines correctly.

The question, then, is whether the benefit justifies the cost and risks. Unfortunately the answer is not forthcoming, again because of the TSA's fetish for secrecy. We're presumably supposed to accept that the benefit justifies the cost and risks based on trust and faith in the TSA. Many people may have had faith and trust in the TSA up until now, based perhaps on a fervent desire for the government to protect us. But I think the combination of unprecedented intrusiveness and the contemptuous way the TSA has chosen to roll out these "enhancements" has caused an increasing number of people to finally lose faith and trust. Thus the backlash we're now seeing.

Pistole's claims that the "invasive" strip search or pat down are absolutely necessary and justified by current threats may be honest and accurate. But given the TSA's unfortunate reputation, I don't think we should just quietly accept a costly, invasive, uncomfortable security measure just because the agency's leader took time away from his busy schedule to tell us to accept it.

It really is time to subject the TSA to a thorough independent review and cost-benefit analysis, to make sure we're actually getting something for what their "security" is costing us.

I wonder how many people have died because they chose to drive rather than subject themselves to  TSA hassles. I doubt any government bean counters have compiled such statistics. But I'm sure it be more than the number of lives TSA screening has saved-- zero.

How exactly would current airport security stop a person from personally crashing his plane into an IRS building? Maybe shooting it down would, but it doesn't seem likely that would happen quickly enough. Psychological screenings of pilots? Again, I doubt that would stop all the depressed people out there.

For all the talk that profiling misses some would-be terrorists, the vast majority of 'serious' terrorists (not one man operations) would be easily caught by profiling.

"And I thought, wow, there’s no line of people waiting to get into St. Patrick’s Cathedral, and the treasure in there is of eternal value. What can I do to help our great people appreciate that tradition?”
Well, I don't know; maybe stop treating thinking people as if they're cognitively challenged children incapable of making decisions based on their own moral conscience? Sorry Mr. Dolan, but I'll continue to decide for myself what's right and wrong. Especially after the fine job you and your peers have done modeling the worst of human behavior.

(From a former altar boy:)
Religion co-opts morality from nature to give itself credence. Child molestation is the direct inverse of morality. The Catholic Church has lost all credibility.
I blogged on this at:
http://www.motormanmark.com/?p=261

Could the NYT have posted a less flattering photo? The bias against the Catholic Church is always evident in any and all forms of its "ALL the news thats fit to print". The "Gray Lady" has been in steep decline for decades...sad indeed.

Suggestions for the Roman Catholic Church:

Stop (previous) practices of hiding + relocating known pedophile priests.

Permit priests to marry (heterosexual or homosexual)

Accept abstinence does not prevent unwanted procreation or spreading HIV, STDs, HPV.

Almost all of the Catholics I know have stopped attending mass (often after a lifetime of regular attendance) because the church cannot see the plank in it's own eye: the hypocrisy of hiding child rapists in its own ranks, of working against health care for the poor while preaching 'respect for life,' just to name two examples. The church is willing to undo health care because it's possible for some to use it to obtain an abortion, yet priests campaign for politicians who advocate nuclear-war policies, the death penalty, and the immoral war in Iraq in which thousands of women and children died. Anyone who goes to church to hear one of those simple-minded sermons that the bishop refers to, sermons that seem to be written by men with grade-school educations for grade-school children, can't help but notice that most of the families in attendance consist of two children, even though the church opposes any reasonable birth control. That is, Catholics are leaving the church in droves because in its drive toward radical, doctrinaire thinking, the church is making itself irrelevant to both modern life and Christ's teachings.

More Bible less politics, and more mercy, as a Catholic one can not receive communion unless married in the church, can you imagine Christ turning away the Sammaritan woman at the well because of who she was or her marital status, because of it she received his mercy and we have one of the most beautiful stories in the word of God.

My Dad left your church in 1946 for reasons related to hypocrisy and corruption. Yo, listen up. Take your church forward and liberalize, elevate charity over faith, or consign yourself to a subservient third-world membership.

Perhaps the USA is simply abandoning superstition and following other advanced nations away from church membership.
Europe leads the US in this, church membership and attendance have been dropping in Europe for years.
The Church is a medieval institution and will eventuality give way to more rational options like Buddhism which provides both a philosophy for life and a means of attaining enlightenment, meditation, but which has no god and no priests. Or perhaps people will simply become ateeists. There is no conflict between atheism and Buddhism as far as I know. Buddhism has no god, the Buddha never claimed to be divine, in fact he denied divinity. He simply claimed to be 'awake'.
Catholicism is a set of rituals in search of a secret friend.

Allow women and married people to become priests (Christ did not forbid this) and watch the priesthood become healthier.  Exclude these two huge groups and you will have problems recruiting and retaining good priests.
There is no such thing as a "healthy, happy celibacy."

For starters, the Church might abandon the ignorance of the past — pre-Christian Greek medicine, for instance — and make use of the knowledge of today in dealing with human sexuality. Its approach to homosexuality and celibacy in particular is ignorant, wrong and immoral. But change of this sort is probably too much to hope for because, as history teaches us, it takes the Church centuries, if not millennia, to acknowledge error.

It looks like the Roman Catholic Church is keeping its collective head in the sand as usual.  The archbishop seems (to me) to be like the SEC - why change anything, things are just fine the way they are.  "Don't worry, be happy!"

This Dolan guy is loco crazy. Another self-appointed member of the royal household who has no clue about daily life for those of us who are not super wealthy like he is. He is a sham, a shame, a shyster with really nothing important to say. The dreary fiction Dolan preaches is avoided by anyone with a modicum of intelligence.
One priest like Padre Pio or the Curé of Ars will bring New York Catholics back to Mass.

As a pro-choice Catholic who favors same-sex marriage and who sometimes takes Communion from a female priest (ordained by a bishop who will remain nameless to protect him from persecution), the Pope's tepid comment about condoms is too little too late to save him from ridicule. I pray for him to rectify his errors. Many of us do. He's wrong on so many matters and I want him to see the light.

comments.userDisplayName: This is one encouraging piece of news
comments.commentBody: in an otherwise gloomy world news environment. Climate change -- being ignored. Economy -- going to get worse. Nuclear arms reduction -- no. Afghanistan -- not much good. But AT LEAST people seem to have enough sense to turn away from Catholicism in increasing numbers, despite the church's best efforts to frighten and control them.

As one of the 1/3 of baptized Catholics who have left the church, I can tell you it is because of leaders like Dolan who believe that a modern church can: 1) Discriminate against women and gays 2) Support the Republican agenda and deny communion to politicians and parishioners who oppose it 3) Continue to bar women and married men from serving as priests while to this day shielding pedophiles who have used their position to exploit children 4) Promote teachings like the recent pronouncement on the use of condoms that are ridiculous in a modern world. The men who "lead" the Catholic church are ensuring that the church becomes smaller and smaller. Those of us who love Christ and the spirit of the Catholic church have sadly found that God's love is outside of the Roman Catholic church. Old men in Rome and the young men like Dolan who adhere to old ideas are attempting to turn back the reforms of Vatican II in the mistaken belief that these led to recent scandals and the loss of parishioners. The Catholic church will either take a modern approach to Christ's simple commandments: love God and one another as yourself. Or it will continue to shrink and become irrlevant.

"He said the bishops would not stop speaking out on political issues like abortion, same-sex marriage and immigration."

THEN START PAYING TAXES!!!! I'm gay and would like to marry my partner. And I pay taxes. The church, which doesn't pay taxes feels it has the right to deny me that marriage right?

How does that make sense? (and I don't intend to infer that if they paid taxes that they should have the right to deny me the right to marry).

I am one of those mentioned. Born Catholic and left the church. The bishops' efforts to restore the religion as it is will be futile. Now, more than ever, the world is fast-changing and this religion's (as with other religion's) inability to go with the irresistible shapes of reality will perhaps make it extinct in the future. Its teachings are stale, irrelevant, and most importantly divisive.
His lack of provocative remarks presage continued loss of communicants. If the "C"hurch abides or connives with Republicans on the demise of improved health care, even Jesus will leave.

The only way for the Church to win back former Catholics is to grow up. The institution is mirrored in medieval superstition and prejudice. Jesus was a great moral teacher. The dogmas and ridiculous magical thinking of the Church moved far from that morality. A modern person can no longer take the nonsense seriously.
